Summary of amendments/ Record documents superseded by:
Full review; added additional cardiac liaison nurses; individualised area of speciality. New template and log.

data.text: This policy has been developed to define the service provided by the Cardiac Nurse Practitioners at Mid South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

To provide a high quality patient centred care as part of Cardiology service. The service is flexible to the changing needs of the population of Broomfield Hospital, serving both inpatient and outpatient activity.
The service provides access to Consultant Cardiologists, Nuclear Medicine, cardiology investigations and specialist nurse services, via Broomfield Hospital inpatient and outpatient settings.

The service is responsive, accepting inpatient consultation requests from other clinical teams within Broomfield Hospital to enable and facilitate appropriate specialist management of cardiology conditions and expedite patient discharge.
National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE)
Work across professional and organisational boundaries
To provide high quality holistic patient care encompassing mental, emotional needs of the patient as much as physical problems.
Provide expert nursing practice for patients admitted under the spectrum of Acute coronary syndrome (ACS), Atrial Fibrillation (AF), Heart Failure (HF) and other cardiology conditions.
Provide better outcomes for patients admitted with ACS, AF, HF and other cardiac anomalies by improving service, quality and access to investigations and treatment
Provide professional leadership and support to junior nursing staff ensuring significance of planned care is understood
Work with patients within a clearly defined area of clinical practice
Involved in service strategy development – NICE, networking with local cardiac

Assist in stream lining the patient's pathway, facilitating transfer for treatment reducing inpatient length of stay by anticipating and requesting appropriate cardiac investigations thus expediting early discharge of “low risk” cardiac patients, ensuring outpatient follow up as required
In conjunction with Nuclear Medicine to provide Myocardial Perfusion Scan clinic service to local population as required
Manage direct current cardioversion lists in conjunction with the angiography suite
Ensure individual nurses manage their caseload ensuring prompt assessment & treatment of patients referred to RACPC, Arrhythmia and Heart Failure clinics
Develop and implement service improvement initiatives where appropriate;
Follow up of appropriate troponin positive Cardiology patients
Review of cardiac admissions to Emergency Village
Liaise with Emergency Village to identify appropriate patients requiring cardiology investigations and referral;
Liaise with Emergency Village to identify appropriate patients for transfer cardiology ward at Basildon Hospital
Liaise with Cardiology Consultants and Specialist Nurse Team when and where appropriate to provide continuity and consistency of the cardiac service
Provide rapid assessment of Arrhythmias in consultation with admitting Consultant to identify those patients requiring cardiology investigation and review as outpatient
Provide a link between the medical and nursing teams to ensure excellent communication
Provide rapid assessment and management of patients admitted with heart failure to expedite discharge with referral onwards to community services
Adult population of Mid-Essex requiring review by Cardiac Nurse Practitioners
No paediatric intervention or investigation is undertaken within this service.

The Head of Nursing for Acute Medicine is operationally and financially accountable for service delivery. The Clinical Team will remain professionally accountable for their actions and report professionally to the Chief Nurse. The Clinical Team will work in conjunction with the Lead Nurse to ensure that the service is delivered within the confines of the agreed budget and operational requirements.

09143 Cardiac nurse practitioner clinical operational policy 4.0.005.png

data.text: Patients access the service via emergency, wards and elective pathways.
Office space with computer to allow for locating inpatients, accessing results and patient records, enabling administration, telephone consultations and conducting MDTs.
Allocated appointment times to enable patients to return for outpatient cardiology investigations within a specified timeframe
7.3.1 This service is predominately delivered through host departments and therefore does not have any specific requirement.
7.3.2 Each host department has a service level agreement for domestic services and access to the Estates and Facilities department via the non-stock requisition line.
7.3.3 Consumables for the service are provided by the host department or ordered via the Commercial Services Department.
7.4.1  As previously stated this service is delivered in host departments i.e. Cardiac Centre Environmental requirements have been addressed within the department in their Clinical Operation policy.
7.5.1 All out-patients attending this service are advised to follow the signage to the Cardiac Department.

7.5.2 This signage is available at all points of entry to the Hospital. Patients using this service via the in-patient setting are conveyed to the department by the portering team which is accessed via the pager system.
7.5.3 Patients arriving for all outpatient appointments are advised to present to The Cardiac Centre.
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's IT policies
Data sharing agreements will be drawn up to cover all data sharing outside the Trust in accordance with the Trust data sharing policy
Hospital information/patient data will only be downloaded onto devices provided by the Trust which are encrypted
Patient identifiable information will only be sent out of the Trust from an nhs.net account or other secure route (never from an nhs.uk account)
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Patient Safety Policies.
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Lone Worker and Security/Risk Management Policies.
All patients medical records will be managed confidentially at all times and stored securely in locked office or outpatient facility whilst not in use
All movement of patient's records will be accurately tracked in accordance with the Trust's Case note Tracking Policy
All new documentation will be secured into the folder prior to it leaving the Department
7.7.1  The service will be compliant with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures.”
(The detail of these items will then be developed as part of the separate Fire Safety Work Programme, as led by the Trust's Fire Officer.)
7.8.1  Access to the following IT systems:
This service has a funded establishment of 4.11 WTE Band
It is the responsibility of the Cardiac Nurse Practitioner to have undertaken the following mandatory training and update as necessary:

The Cardiac Nurse Practitioner should have a current ILS or ALS and maintain their own requirements for continuous development and be able to demonstrate requirements of the NMC. The Cardiac Nurse Practitioners are all nurse prescribers and have been deemed competent to perform myocardial perfusion and DCCV as agreed by the lead Cardiology Consultant.
10.1.1 The Cardiac Nurse Practitioners will require access to washrooms, lockers for
personal items and refreshment facilities. These facilities are currently available in the Cardiac Centre.
Specific items required for the Cardiac Nurse Practitioner service are Alaris and Braun Infusion Devices to administer Adenosine and Dobutamine.
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliant to the Trust's Infection Control Policies.
CNS clinic activity is scheduled to allow for annual leave requirements whilst still maintaining the  week targets.
In the event of sickness during annual leave, nurse led clinics may need to be cancelled. In the event of Major Incident, CNS activity may cease as directed to support Hospital during the incident.
In the event of IT failure, paper documentation will be completed and uploaded when IT systems are re-established.
In the event of Pathology Review being unavailable, urgent results can be obtained from the Pathology Department via the telephone system.
It is the responsibility of the Cardiac Nurse Practitioner to identify incidents and report risks, using the Trust risk management strategy policy
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Individual practitioners are responsible for monitoring their own individual service
Feedback through departmental meetings. Individual appraisel

data.text: This policy will be audited by the Cardiac Nurse Practitioners Audit information will be shared at the Emergency Care Bilateral

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Cardiac Nurse practitioners which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local Cardiac Lead Nurse guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Lead Nurse - Cardiologyof the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.

National Institute of Clinical Excellence, 2014. Acute heart failure: diagnosis and management. Clinical guideline [CG187]. [Online] NICE (Published 2014) Available at: https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg187> [Accessed th February 2018]
